Andrea Blasco

Andrea Blasco is a research fellow at Harvard University Institute for Quantitative Social Science (IQSS) and member of the Crowd Innovation Laboratory (CIL) at Harvard University. Blasco is an applied economist focusing on intellectual property rights, innovation contests, crowdsourcing, and media economics. For more information, see his curriculum vitae.



Research

Here you can find research papers and presentations.

Papers

  • Blasco, A., Jung, O. S., Lakhani, K. R., & Menietti, M. (2016). Motivating Effort In Contributing to Public Goods Inside Organizations: Field Experimental Evidence (No. w22189). National Bureau of Economic Research.

  • Blasco, A., Pin, P., & Sobbrio, F. (2016). Paying positive to go negative: Advertisers׳ competition and media reports. European Economic Review, 83, 243-261.

  • Blasco, A. (2015). Strategic Collaboration in Dynamic R&D Competitions. Institute for Quantitative Social Sciences.

  • Blasco, A., Boudreau, K. J., Lakhani, K. R., Menietti, M., & Riedl, C. (2013). Do Crowds have the Wisdom to Self-Organize?.

  • Blasco, A., & Sobbrio, F. (2012). Competition and commercial media bias. Telecommunications Policy, 36(5), 434-447.

  • Blasco, A., & Pin, P. (2010). Simulations on Correlated Behavior and Social Learning. In Progress in Artificial Economics (pp. 89-100). Springer Berlin Heidelberg.

Presentations

  • December 8, 2016. IGL Winter Research Meeting, Harvard Business School, Cambridge US

  • September 16, 2016. Advances with Field Experiments, The University of Chicago, Chicago, US

Research interests

  • Methods
    • Design of Experiments
    • Applied econometrics
  • Theory
    • Contract theory
    • Innovation Contest
    • Media economics
    • Social network
    • Learning
  • Markets
    • Online Labor Markets (Odesk, Amazon Mechanical Turk)
    • Crowdsourcing platforms (Topcoder, Innocentive)
    • News media (online and offline)
